title: Jellyfish hugging robot uses its 'palm' to safely capture creatures for scientific studies
text:
A team of engineers from Harvard have developed a robot that will allow researchers to capture jellyfish without physically damaging them.

The robot was designed to mimic the human hand and gently grasp jellyfish, whose delicate bodies are 95 per cent water.

The device could be a major breakthrough for jellyfish researchers, who have long struggled with ways to study the mysterious sea creatures without damaging their delicate body.

Scroll down for video

The exciting new device has a 3D-printed central housing meant to mimic a palm. The long soft silicon tubes can be filled with water, causing them to curl around the jellyfish without harming it

The device is made with six long silicone tubes that are designed to act like fingers.

Each tube can be filled with water, which causes the tubes to curl upward toward a 3D printed, palm-like rectangular housing.

The silicone tubes for a soft, cage around the jellyfish and keep it immobile without damaging its soft outer surface.

HOW DO JELLYFISH BREED? Jellyfish even reproduce in different ways during their life cycles. Adults spawn, releasing a huge quantity of eggs and sperm into the water. The fertilised eggs sink to the ocean depths before hatching a small polyp, which can then clone itself. When vast numbers of jellyfish mass together it is known as a 'bloom'. In the past these would happen at regular intervals, every 12 years in the Mediterranean, for example. Due to a variety of human-caused phenomena, this is now happening every year.

'If we aren't able to safely hold and handle these animals without damaging them, then it makes it really hard to study them,' Hannah Stuart, a mechanical engineer at University of California, Berkeley, told Science News for Students.

Jellyfish were among the first complex lifeforms on Earth, having evolved an estimated 500 million years ago.

In the past, jellyfish would gather in what scientists call a 'bloom' at different locations around the world.

In the Mediterranean, this would happen every twelve years.

Today, these blooms occur every year, something scientists still aren't sure they understand.

To date, scientists have identified 200 different species of jellyfish, but some believe there could be thousands that haven't yet been identified.
description: Jellyfish are among the oldest life forms on Earth, but they're still a mystery. A new hand-like robot that allows scientists to capture the animals without harming them could lead to a breakthrough.
